title: Stakeholder Adoption and Interoperability
statement: These requirements have since been used by a variety of stakeholders, including the Open Health Information Exchange (OpenHIE), the open source Health Insurance Management Information System (openIMIS), and several country governments, including that of Bangladesh.
acceptance_criteria: The system's architecture and data exchange protocols must be compliant with OpenHIE standards.
The system must demonstrate interoperability with openIMIS or systems based on its framework.
Evidence of alignment with the digital health requirements of specified country governments (e.g., Bangladesh) must be provided.

metadata.raw_input: These requirements have since been used by a variety of stakeholders, including the Open Health Information Exchange (OpenHIE), the open source Health Insurance Management Information System (openIMIS), and several country governments, including that of Bangladesh.

title: Update National Health Insurance System Requirements Guide
statement: A 'Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems' must be updated, based on the results of the Determining workshop, to supersede the 2012 version of the document.
acceptance_criteria: A new version of the 'Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems' is published.
The new guide incorporates all relevant outputs from the 'Determining workshop'.
The new guide is formally approved and designated as the replacement for the 2012 document.

metadata.raw_input: A Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems This document, , is the result of that Determining workshop and the next step toward updating the content of the 2012 document.

title: Update National Health Insurance Information Systems Guide
statement: The 'Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems' must be updated to incorporate the results of the 'Determining workshop', serving as the official replacement for the 2012 version of the document.
acceptance_criteria: A new version of the 'Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems' is drafted and approved.
The new guide explicitly incorporates the findings and decisions from the 'Determining workshop'.
The updated document is officially published and communicated as the replacement for the 2012 version.

metadata.raw_input: A Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems This document, , is the result of that Determining workshop and the next step toward updating the content of the 2012 document.

title: Living Document Contribution Process
statement: In addition, this document suggests a way forward for the insurance technology community to contribute to ongoing updates to ensure these requirements continue to have value as a living resource.
acceptance_criteria: A formal process for submitting proposed updates is defined and documented.
A mechanism (e.g., web portal, version control repository) is established for the community to submit contributions.
The process for reviewing, approving, and integrating contributions is established and communicated.
The 'living resource' is updated at least once based on a community contribution.

metadata.raw_input: In addition, this document suggests a way forward for the insurance technology community to contribute to ongoing updates to ensure these requirements continue to have value as a living resource.

title: National Health Insurance System Context
statement: The system must be designed in the context of a national health insurance system, which operationalizes health financing transactions for paying for and delivering health services as part of a country's progress toward Universal Health Coverage for its citizens.
acceptance_criteria: The system's purpose and design documentation must align with the principles of supporting a national health insurance framework.
Stakeholder documentation confirms the system's role in contributing to Universal Health Coverage goals.

metadata.raw_input: A guide to common requirements for nAtionAl heAlth insurAnce informAtion systems PAge 5 Introduction National health insurance systems are becoming more common as countries move to operationalize health financing transactions of paying for and delivering health services as part of their progress toward Universal Health Coverage for their citizens.

title: Process for Ongoing Requirement Updates
statement: A process must be established for the insurance technology community to contribute to ongoing updates, ensuring the requirements document remains a valuable and current 'living resource' to support national health insurance systems and Universal Health Coverage goals.
acceptance_criteria: A formal process for submitting, reviewing, and incorporating updates to the requirements is documented and approved.
A designated group or role is assigned responsibility for managing the update process.
A communication channel is established for the insurance technology community to provide contributions and feedback.
The requirements document is scheduled for periodic review (e.g., annually) to ensure its continued value.

metadata.raw_input: In addition, this document suggests a way forward for the insurance technology community to contribute to ongoing updates to ensure these requirements continue to have value as a living resource. A guide to common requirements for nAtionAl heAlth insurAnce informAtion systems PAge 5 Introduction National health insurance systems are becoming more common as countries move to operationalize health financing transactions of paying for and delivering health services as part of their progress toward Universal Health Coverage for their citizens.

title: Support for National Scale Health Schemes
statement: Health insurance or health purchaser information systems must be designed and implemented to support schemes at a national scale, ensuring performance, reliability, and compliance.
acceptance_criteria: The system must demonstrate performance and scalability to support a user base and data volume consistent with a national-scale implementation.
The system architecture must be proven to be reliable, with a defined uptime SLA (e.g., 99.9%) under projected load.
The system must pass a compliance audit against all applicable national-level regulations for health information.

metadata.raw_input: As a result, health insurance or health purchaser1 information systems are becoming more important as schemes are implemented at national scale.

title: Health Insurance Information System Efficacy
statement: Strong health insurance information systems can ensure timely reimbursements, decrease transaction costs, find system efficiencies, prevent fraud, and ensure equitable coverage and treatment.
acceptance_criteria: The system must process 95% of standard electronic claims for reimbursement within 14 business days.
The system must demonstrate a 10% reduction in cost-per-claim-processed compared to the previous system within the first year of operation.
The system must include reporting dashboards that identify bottlenecks in the claims processing workflow, such as average time spent in each status.
The system must automatically flag claims that match predefined fraud-detection rules with a 98% accuracy rate on a test dataset.
The system must be able to generate audit reports to verify that claims are adjudicated based on policy rules without statistical bias related to patient demographics.

metadata.raw_input: Strong health insurance information systems can ensure timely reimbursements, decrease transaction costs, find system efficiencies, prevent fraud, and ensure equitable coverage and treatment.

title: Health Insurance Information System Core Capabilities
statement: The health insurance information system must support national-scale schemes by providing functionalities to ensure timely reimbursements, decrease transaction costs, identify system efficiencies, prevent fraud, and ensure equitable coverage and treatment for all members.
acceptance_criteria: The system must process 95% of standard electronic claims for reimbursement within 5 business days.
The system must demonstrate a measurable reduction in transaction cost per claim compared to baseline metrics.
The system must include an analytics module that generates reports identifying potential system efficiencies, such as common claim denial reasons or underutilized provider networks.
The system must implement fraud detection algorithms that flag suspicious claims based on predefined rules and patterns, generating alerts for review by a compliance officer.
The system must enforce business rules to ensure coverage and treatment options are applied consistently and equitably across all member demographics, verifiable through audit reports.
The system must be scalable to support a national-level user base and transaction volume without performance degradation below defined Service Level Agreements (SLAs).

metadata.raw_input: As a result, health insurance or health purchaser1 information systems are becoming more important as schemes are implemented at national scale. Strong health insurance information systems can ensure timely reimbursements, decrease transaction costs, find system efficiencies, prevent fraud, and ensure equitable coverage and treatment.

title: Health Insurance Data Integration
statement: The system shall be capable of ingesting, processing, and integrating health insurance data to complement other existing health system data sources, such as clinical records or lab results.
acceptance_criteria: The system provides a mechanism to connect to and ingest data from a specified health insurance data source.
Ingested health insurance data is correctly parsed and stored in a structured format.
The system can successfully link health insurance records to the corresponding patient records within the main health system.
Authorized users can query and view the combined dataset of health system data and complementary insurance data.
All actions involving access and integration of health insurance data are logged in an audit trail.

metadata.raw_input: Many countries are also finding value in health insurance data to complement other types of health system data.

title: Health Insurance Data Integration
statement: The system shall be capable of ingesting and integrating health insurance data to complement other types of health system data, such as clinical or demographic data.
acceptance_criteria: The system provides a secure mechanism (e.g., API, SFTP) to import health insurance data.
Imported health insurance data can be successfully parsed and stored in a secure, encrypted manner.
The system can link imported insurance data to the correct patient records within the existing health system.
Authorized users can view a consolidated record that displays both clinical data and complementary insurance data for a patient.
All access to and import of health insurance data is logged in an immutable audit trail.

metadata.raw_input: Many countries are also finding value in health insurance data to complement other types of health system data.

title: Value and Use of Functional Requirements
statement: Functional requirements are an invaluable tool for policymakers and systems engineering, and technical experts alike.
acceptance_criteria: A formal process for defining, reviewing, and approving functional requirements is established and followed.
Stakeholders from policymaking, systems engineering, and technical domains are engaged in the requirements lifecycle.

metadata.raw_input: Functional requirements are an invaluable tool for policymakers and systems engineering, and technical experts alike.

title: Provide National Healthcare Priorities in a Transferable Format
statement: The system shall provide authorized system experts with access to national healthcare priorities. This information must be presented in a structured, machine-readable format (e.g., JSON, XML) that is transferable to other software components.
acceptance_criteria: Given an authenticated system expert, when they navigate to the priorities section, then the system must display the current national healthcare priorities.
Given the national priorities are displayed, when the expert selects the export option, then the system must generate a file in a valid, machine-readable format (e.g., JSON).
Verify that the exported data structure conforms to the defined schema for national priorities.
Verify that unauthorized users cannot access or export the national priorities data.

metadata.raw_input: Technical defines a function of a system experts gain clarity on the national priorities in a format that is transferable to software or its component, where a design and implementation.

title: Understandable Requirement Format
statement: The requirement specification format must be clear and understandable to both non-technical stakeholders (e.g., health insurance experts) and technical teams (e.g., software engineers). This format shall serve as a common platform for defining system behavior, prioritizing features, negotiating compromises, and guiding system design.
acceptance_criteria: A sample requirement can be reviewed by a designated health insurance expert and a software engineer, and both can articulate the same understanding of the expected behavior.
The requirement specification format is formally documented and adopted by the project team.
Stakeholders from both business and engineering teams confirm the format provides sufficient clarity for their respective roles during a review session.

metadata.raw_input: These requirements provide a format that is understandable function is described as a to both health insurance experts and software engineers, providing a platform for specification of behavior prioritization, compromise, and system design.

title: Standardized Requirement Specification Format
statement: The system shall provide a standardized, transferable format for defining system functions and specifications. This format must be understandable to both non-technical stakeholders (e.g., health insurance experts) and technical teams (e.g., software engineers) to provide a common platform for clarifying priorities, facilitating compromise, and guiding system design and implementation.
acceptance_criteria: A template for defining requirements is available within the system.
The template includes distinct fields for business-level descriptions and technical implementation details.
A sample requirement created using the format can be successfully interpreted and agreed upon by a designated health insurance expert and a software engineer.
The output format is transferable and can be exported for use in software development and design tools.

metadata.raw_input: Technical defines a function of a system experts gain clarity on the national priorities in a format that is transferable to software or its component, where a design and implementation. These requirements provide a format that is understandable function is described as a to both health insurance experts and software engineers, providing a platform for specification of behavior prioritization, compromise, and system design.

title: Jurisdictional Requirement Configuration
statement: The system must be configurable to allow a country or organization to define and enforce specific requirements according to its local regulatory, clinical, and operational needs.
acceptance_criteria: An administrator must be able to define a new set of rules for a specific country or organization.
The system must enforce the newly defined rules, such as data masking or access control, based on the active jurisdiction's configuration.
It must be possible to have different rule sets active for different organizational units or jurisdictions simultaneously within the same system instance.

metadata.raw_input: A country or organization will define specific requirements for its specific needs.

title: Common Requirements Baseline
statement: A set of globally defined common requirements shall be established and used as an advanced starting point to review best practices and save time and resources in the development process.
acceptance_criteria: A documented set of globally defined common requirements exists and is accessible to the development team.
Evidence demonstrates that new projects reference and incorporate applicable common requirements from the defined set.
A process is in place for the periodic review and update of the common requirements set.

metadata.raw_input: The benefit of a set of globally defined common requirements is to provide an advanced starting point to review best practices and save time and resources in the development process.

title: Use of Global Requirements Baseline
statement: The development process shall utilize a set of globally defined common requirements as an advanced starting point to review best practices and save time and resources. Country- or organization-specific requirements will be defined and adapted from this common foundation to address unique needs.
acceptance_criteria: Evidence is provided that a recognized set of common/global requirements was used as the initial baseline for project requirements.
A formal review process is documented, showing how the global requirements were evaluated and adapted for specific country or organizational needs.
Traceability is established between the project-specific requirements and the initial global requirements baseline.

metadata.raw_input: A country or organization will define specific requirements for its specific needs. The benefit of a set of globally defined common requirements is to provide an advanced starting point to review best practices and save time and resources in the development process.

title: Support for Diverse Health Coverage Schemes
statement: Country health coverage schemes range in design, coverage, and maturity—all of which require different types of requirements to function appropriately.
acceptance_criteria: The system architecture must be designed to be adaptable to different country-specific health coverage rules.
An administrative interface must exist to configure the parameters of a given health coverage scheme (e.g., co-pay rules, covered services, eligibility criteria).
The system must be able to process patient data and apply billing/coverage rules correctly for at least two distinct, pre-configured country schemes.
Documentation must be available outlining the process for configuring a new country-specific health scheme.

metadata.raw_input: Country health coverage schemes range in design, coverage, and maturity—all of which require different types of requirements to function appropriately.

title: Adaptability to Diverse Health Coverage Schemes
statement: The system must be designed to accommodate and adapt to a variety of country-specific health coverage schemes, which differ in design, coverage levels, and maturity. This includes the ability to configure different types of requirements and rules to function appropriately within each specific national or regional context.
acceptance_criteria: The system provides a configuration interface for an administrator to define rules for a new health coverage scheme.

It is possible to configure and enable at least two distinct country health coverage models (e.g., a US-based private insurance model and a European single-payer model) to run concurrently without conflict.
Configuration of a new scheme's rules (e.g., coverage limits, co-pays, deductibles) does not require a new software deployment or code changes.
System successfully processes a test claim according to the rules of each configured country scheme.

metadata.raw_input: CreAting common requirements While common requirements are a useful building block, creating them can be a challenge. Country health coverage schemes range in design, coverage, and maturity—all of which require different types of requirements to function appropriately.

title: CRDM Application Scope
statement: Since its development, CRDM has been used not only in the health insurance space but also to develop requirements for logistics management information systems, maternal health information systems, and more.
acceptance_criteria: The system's data model, based on CRDM, is validated to support core use cases for health insurance systems.
The system's data model, based on CRDM, is validated to support core use cases for logistics management information systems.
The system's data model, based on CRDM, is validated to support core use cases for maternal health information systems.

metadata.raw_input: Since its development, CRDM has been used not only in the health insurance space but also to develop requirements for logistics management information systems, maternal health information systems, and more.

title: User-Friendly Terminology
statement: The system shall use non-technical language that is familiar to its intended users and subject matter experts to ensure effectiveness and clarity in all user-facing interfaces, reports, and documentation.
acceptance_criteria: All user-facing text (labels, error messages, help text) is written in plain language, avoiding technical jargon.
Usability testing with representative users confirms that terminology is understood with a comprehension rate of 95% or higher.
A glossary of terms used within the system is available to all users and is approved by a panel of subject matter experts.

metadata.raw_input: A key aspect of the effectiveness of CRDM is the use of nontechnical language that is familiar to users and subject matter experts.

title: Use of Non-Technical Language
statement: The system shall use nontechnical language, terminology, and phrasing that is familiar to its intended users and subject matter experts to ensure clarity, reduce errors, and improve effectiveness.
acceptance_criteria: A glossary of all user-facing terms is created and approved by a panel of representative subject matter experts and end-users.
Usability testing with a representative group of end-users demonstrates that 95% of users can understand and correctly interpret system labels, instructions, and messages without external help.
During user acceptance testing, no critical or major issues related to confusing or technical language are identified.

metadata.raw_input: Since its development, CRDM has been used not only in the health insurance space but also to develop requirements for logistics management information systems, maternal health information systems, and more. A key aspect of the effectiveness of CRDM is the use of nontechnical language that is familiar to users and subject matter experts.

title: Beneficiary Management Capability
statement: While some schemes may not require beneficiary enrollment and another may require it, both systems will require some level of beneficiary management.
acceptance_criteria: An authorized user can create a beneficiary record in the system.
An authorized user can search for and view the details of an existing beneficiary.
An authorized user can update the information of an existing beneficiary.
An authorized user can change the status of a beneficiary (e.g., active, inactive, archived).
All actions related to beneficiary management are logged in an audit trail.

metadata.raw_input: While some schemes may not require beneficiary enrollment and another may require it, both systems will require some level of beneficiary management.

title: Interoperability via Global Standards
statement: The system shall leverage global standards, such as HL7 FHIR, for data exchange to ensure alignment of business processes and interoperability across disparate digital health systems.
acceptance_criteria: The system's data exchange APIs must be compliant with the specified version of the HL7 FHIR standard.
All data exchange transactions must be successfully validated against a standard FHIR validator tool.
System must demonstrate successful data exchange (e.g., sending a patient summary, receiving lab results) with a third-party test system.
All data exchanged must be encrypted in transit using industry-standard protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2+).
Audit logs are created for all data exchange events, in compliance with HIPAA requirements.

metadata.raw_input: HL7 FHIR HL7 FHIR, and other global standards for data exchange, are helpful frameworks for aligning business processes across digital health systems.

title: Interoperability via Global Standards
statement: The system shall utilize global standards, such as HL7 FHIR, for data exchange to ensure interoperability and alignment of business processes across different digital health systems.
acceptance_criteria: Data exported for key workflows (e.g., patient transfer, lab results reporting) must be in a valid HL7 FHIR format.
The system must successfully consume and correctly process HL7 FHIR-formatted data from a certified external system.
All data exchange transmissions must be encrypted using industry-standard protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2+).
A compliance report must be available demonstrating that all data exchange endpoints adhere to the specified global standards.

metadata.raw_input: HL7 FHIR HL7 FHIR, and other global standards for data exchange, are helpful frameworks for aligning business processes across digital health systems.

title: Task Set Definition
statement: The system shall allow for the creation, viewing, and management of task sets, defined as a collection of required activities or steps that constitute a business process.
acceptance_criteria: An authorized user (e.g., Admin) can create a new task set with a unique name and description.
The user can add, remove, and reorder individual steps or activities within a task set.
The system displays a list of all defined task sets.
The user can select a task set to view its detailed configuration and associated steps.
The user can modify or delete an existing task set, with appropriate confirmations to prevent accidental deletion.

metadata.raw_input: • Task set(s): The set of required activities or steps that are carried out in a business process.

title: Task Set Definition
statement: The system shall support the concept of a Task Set, defined as the set of required activities or steps that are carried out in a business process.
acceptance_criteria: 1. An administrator can create a new Task Set within the system.
2. A Task Set can be configured to include a sequence of one or more steps or activities.
3. The system can associate a Task Set with a specific business process.
4. A user can view the activities and steps defined within a Task Set they are assigned to execute.

metadata.raw_input: • Task set(s): The set of required activities or steps that are carried out in a business process.

title: Scheme Process Customization
statement: By outlining these differences, countries will understand the breadth of options available and choose those processes that are most relevant to their scheme.
acceptance_criteria: Given an administrator is configuring a country's scheme,
When the administrator navigates to the process selection section,
Then the system must display a list of all available processes.
And for each process, the system must provide a clear description outlining its function and how it differs from other options.
And the administrator must be able to select one or more processes and save the configuration for their scheme.

metadata.raw_input: By outlining these differences, countries will understand the breadth of options available and choose those processes that are most relevant to their scheme.

title: Business Process Visualization
statement: A graphical representation of a business process helps tell a story of who participates in a process, what types of information are exchanged between the participants, and how the work is accomplished.
acceptance_criteria: The system shall provide a graphical interface to model and view business processes.
The graphical representation must clearly distinguish and label all actors/roles involved in the process.
The flow of information between actors must be visually represented with clear directionality.
The sequence of steps and decision points within the process must be clearly depicted.
The user must be able to export the graphical representation to a standard document format (e.g., PDF, PNG) for auditing and documentation.

metadata.raw_input: A graphical representation of a business process helps tell a story of who participates in a process, what types of information are exchanged between the participants, and how the work is accomplished.

title: Beneficiary Identity and Insurer Verification
statement: The system must support a process where the beneficiary presents proof of identity and accurate insurer identification. The process must conclude with verification of the beneficiary's information to ensure its accuracy.
acceptance_criteria: Given an admin is logged into the system, when they access the patient intake module, they must be presented with fields to capture beneficiary identification and insurance information.
The system must allow the admin to input or scan information from a beneficiary's identification document (e.g., driver's license).
The system must allow the admin to input or scan information from a beneficiary's insurance card.
The system must include a final confirmation step for the admin to verify that the captured information is accurate and matches the documents presented by the beneficiary.
A record of the verification, including the timestamp and the admin's user ID, must be logged in the system's audit trail.

metadata.raw_input: Present identification process and/or process will end with beneficiary to ensure it is information as required by the Beneficiary presents proof of accurate insurer identification 5.

title: Beneficiary Insurer Identification Verification
statement: The system must support a process for verifying a beneficiary's identity by requiring them to present proof of accurate insurer identification. The process must ensure the information is validated as required before proceeding.
acceptance_criteria: The system must provide an interface for an authorized user to capture the beneficiary's insurer identification details.
The system must allow the user to confirm that physical or digital proof of identification was presented by the beneficiary.
The system must validate the captured insurer information for accuracy, either through manual confirmation or automated verification.
An audit trail must be created, logging the user, timestamp, and action of the verification.

metadata.raw_input: Present identification process and/or process will end with beneficiary to ensure it is information as required by the Beneficiary presents proof of accurate insurer identification 5.

title: Beneficiary Identification and Eligibility Verification
statement: The system must allow an Insurer to review a beneficiary's identification information (e.g., name, address, biometrics) and supporting documents to verify their validity and completeness. This review is to ensure the beneficiary qualifies for one or more available benefits plans.
acceptance_criteria: An authorized Insurer user can access the beneficiary's submitted identification information and documents.
The system must display all required fields (e.g., name, address, date of birth) for the Insurer to review.
The system must provide a mechanism for the Insurer to mark the information and documents as 'valid' or 'invalid'.
The system must provide a mechanism for the Insurer to confirm that all required fields are complete.
Upon successful validation, the system correctly identifies and displays the benefits plans for which the beneficiary is eligible.

title: Beneficiary Credential and Plan Qualification Review
statement: The system shall allow an Insurer to review a beneficiary's identification information (e.g., name, address, biometrics) and supporting documents to verify validity and ensure all required data fields are complete. The system must provide a mechanism to manage scenarios where a beneficiary qualifies for multiple benefit plans.
acceptance_criteria: Given an Insurer is logged into the system, when they access a beneficiary's profile, they can view all submitted identification information (name, address, biometrics).
Given an Insurer is reviewing a beneficiary's profile, they can view all submitted supporting documents for validity.
The system shall prevent the completion of the review process if any mandatory fields or documents are missing.
In the event a beneficiary qualifies for multiple benefit plans, the system must display all qualifying plans to the Insurer for selection or further action.

metadata.raw_input: beneficiary credentials Insurer reviews identification information (i.e., name, address, Insurer reviews the captured In the even that there are several and other appropriate qualifying biometrics…) data to ensure that all of the benefits plans for which the documents for validity appropriate fields are complete beneficiary qualifies, then the 6.

title: Requirement Statement Formatting Standard
statement: All system requirement statements must be written in a clear, unambiguous, and testable format, beginning with the phrase 'The system must...'.
acceptance_criteria: A review of the requirements specification document confirms all requirement statements begin with 'The system must...'.
Requirement documents that do not adhere to this standard are rejected during the formal review process.
All requirements are verifiable and traceable as a result of this standardized format.

metadata.raw_input: statements usually begin with “The system must .

title: Requirement Statement Formatting Standard
statement: All requirement statements must begin with the phrase 'The system must...' to ensure clarity, consistency, and testability across all project documentation.
acceptance_criteria: A manual or automated review of the Requirements Specification Document (RSD) confirms that all requirement statements begin with the phrase 'The system must...'.
Requirement authoring tools or templates enforce this formatting standard.
All team members involved in writing requirements have been trained on this standard.

metadata.raw_input: statements usually begin with “The system must .

title: Technology-Agnostic Requirement Formulation
statement: All system requirements must be written to describe what must be accomplished without making specific references to the technology, platform, or implementation details used to achieve it. Requirements should clearly state the necessary outcome or capability.
acceptance_criteria: A review of the requirements specification document confirms that requirements describe functional or non-functional outcomes, not implementation methods.

The requirements specification document does not contain references to specific programming languages, databases, hardware models, or commercial software products unless they are an explicit, pre-approved system constraint.
Each requirement statement is verifiable and testable on its own merit, independent of the technology chosen for implementation.

metadata.raw_input: .”or “The system shall ” and describe what must be accomplished without specific reference to technology.

title: Technology-Agnostic Requirement Formulation
statement: All system requirements must be phrased using the 'The system shall...' format and must describe the necessary functionality or capability without referencing specific technologies, platforms, or implementation details.
acceptance_criteria: All requirements in the specification document start with the phrase 'The system shall'.
A review of the requirements specification confirms the absence of specific technology mentions (e.g., Oracle, AWS, Java, iPhone).
Each requirement is verifiable based on its functional description alone, independent of the implementation.

metadata.raw_input: .”or “The system shall ” and describe what must be accomplished without specific reference to technology.

title: Process Activity Execution
statement: The system must support the execution of the defined process activity.
acceptance_criteria: The system allows an authorized user to initiate the process activity.
The system successfully executes the process activity from start to finish as per the defined workflow.
The system provides a confirmation of success or an error message upon completion of the activity.

metadata.raw_input: Figure 7 Common system requirements example Requirement Req # Process Activity (the system must or should .

title: System Requirement Template Example
statement: This requirement is a placeholder example derived from a document figure (Figure 7), illustrating the format for a system process or activity. The statement template begins with 'the system must or should...'.
acceptance_criteria: Not applicable as this is a placeholder/template requirement. A concrete requirement derived from this template would have specific, measurable criteria.

metadata.raw_input: Figure 7 Common system requirements example Requirement Req # Process Activity (the system must or should .

title: Incorporate Country-Specific Requirements
statement: In turn, country-specific requirements are used to update and expand the global set of requirements.
acceptance_criteria: A documented process exists for identifying and reviewing country-specific requirements.
When a new or updated country-specific requirement is approved, the global requirements set is reviewed for necessary updates or expansions.
Changes to the global requirements set are traceable to the source country-specific requirement.
An audit log captures all modifications to the global requirements set, including the change, the author, and the timestamp.

metadata.raw_input: In turn, country-specific requirements are used to update and expand the global set of requirements.

title: Requirement Contextualization Review
statement: A review of common requirements can help address the question of what requirements are relevant for the context, given national policies and scheme design.
acceptance_criteria: A documented analysis of applicable national policies and scheme design constraints is completed.
A finalized list of relevant system requirements derived from the analysis is created and approved.
Each derived requirement is traced back to a specific policy, scheme design element, or common requirement source.

metadata.raw_input: A review of common requirements can help address the question of what requirements are relevant for the context, given national policies and scheme design.

title: Define Functional Scope
statement: The system shall provide a mechanism for the team to define and document the functional scope of the application.
acceptance_criteria: A user with appropriate permissions can access an interface to define the functional scope.
The user can create, edit, and save functional scope definitions.
The defined scope is stored persistently and can be retrieved for review and reporting.

metadata.raw_input: First, it will allow the team to define what they want to do (i.e., the functional scope).

title: Clinical Inquiry Feature
statement: The system shall provide a secure mechanism for authorized clinical team members to ask essential questions related to a specific patient's care, data, or treatment plan.
acceptance_criteria: A logged-in clinician can initiate a new question and associate it with a specific patient record.
The question content and its association with the patient are transmitted securely over the network using end-to-end encryption.
The question is visible only to other authorized members of the patient's designated care team.
An immutable audit log is created for each question asked, recording the author, recipient(s), patient ID, and timestamp.

metadata.raw_input: It will also allow the team to ask essential questions.

title: Functional Scope Definition
statement: The system or process shall provide the capability for the team to define the functional scope and to ask, document, and track essential questions related to that scope.
acceptance_criteria: A formal process for defining and documenting functional scope is established and approved.
A tool or template is available to capture the functional scope (e.g., a requirements management system, a standardized document).
A mechanism for submitting, tracking, and resolving questions related to the scope is implemented and auditable.
The defined functional scope is version-controlled and requires formal sign-off from designated stakeholders before development begins.

metadata.raw_input: First, it will allow the team to define what they want to do (i.e., the functional scope). It will also allow the team to ask essential questions.

title: Country-Specific Compliance Analysis
statement: The system must be analyzed to identify and incorporate all relevant compliance requirements based on the specific national and local scheme rules of the target country.
acceptance_criteria: A comprehensive list of all applicable national and scheme rules for the target country is documented.
A gap analysis report is produced, comparing system capabilities against the identified rules.
A set of actionable compliance requirements derived from the analysis is created and added to the project backlog.

metadata.raw_input: For example: • What are the requirements that will be relevant for our country context given our national and scheme rules?

title: Provider and Payer System Requirements Definition
statement: The system must support the distinct functional and data exchange requirements for both healthcare provider and payer user groups. This includes defining and developing functionalities for claims processing, eligibility verification, prior authorization, and clinical data exchange between the two parties.
acceptance_criteria: A comprehensive requirements document for the provider-facing module is created, reviewed, and approved by stakeholders.
A comprehensive requirements document for the payer-facing module is created, reviewed, and approved by stakeholders.
The defined requirements cover key workflows such as eligibility checks (270/271), claims submission (837), and remittance advice (835).
All defined requirements are traceable to specific HIPAA Administrative Simplification standards.

metadata.raw_input: • What requirements must be developed on the provider and payer sides?

title: Country-Specific and Role-Based Requirement Analysis
statement: A process must be established to identify and document all relevant healthcare requirements based on the specific country's national laws and local scheme rules. This analysis must differentiate and specify the requirements applicable to the provider and payer sides respectively.
acceptance_criteria: A documented repository of all applicable national and scheme-specific rules for the target country is created.
A final list of system requirements derived from the rules is produced.
Each requirement in the final list is explicitly mapped to the provider system, the payer system, or both.
Traceability is established between each system requirement and its source rule(s).

metadata.raw_input: For example: • What are the requirements that will be relevant for our country context given our national and scheme rules? • What requirements must be developed on the provider and payer sides?

title: Hospital Information System (HIS) Integration
statement: The solution shall provide a defined interface to integrate with existing hospital information systems (HIS) for bidirectional data exchange.
acceptance_criteria: The system successfully establishes a connection with a target HIS using a standard protocol (e.g., HL7, FHIR API).
The system can successfully query and retrieve patient data from the connected HIS.
The system can successfully transmit new data to be stored in the connected HIS.
All data transmitted between the solution and the HIS is encrypted in transit using TLS 1.2 or higher.

metadata.raw_input: • Will the solution integrate with existing hospital information systems, or will it need to have interface design built into it?

title: Requirement Prioritization
statement: The system and development process must support the classification of requirements as 'essential' (must-have) versus 'non-essential' (nice-to-have) to guide prioritization and development efforts.
acceptance_criteria: A mechanism (e.g., a tag, field, or status) is in place to label each requirement as 'essential' or 'nice-to-have'.
The project's requirement backlog can be filtered or sorted based on this classification.
A formal review process is established to determine and approve the classification for each requirement.

metadata.raw_input: • Are there any requirements that are essential to address while others would be nice to have but not essential?

title: HIS Integration and Interoperability
statement: The solution must be capable of integrating with existing hospital information systems (HIS), such as EMRs/EHRs. The integration method, whether using existing standard interfaces (e.g., HL7, FHIR) or requiring custom development, must be defined and implemented.
acceptance_criteria: The system can successfully establish a bi-directional connection with a target HIS in a test environment.
Patient data can be successfully queried and retrieved from the HIS into the solution in a structured format (e.g., FHIR resource, HL7 message).
Data generated by the solution can be successfully transmitted to the HIS, if required by the workflow.
All data transmitted between the solution and the HIS is encrypted in transit using strong, industry-standard protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2+).
The integration handles connection errors and data synchronization issues gracefully without data loss or corruption.

metadata.raw_input: • Will the solution integrate with existing hospital information systems, or will it need to have interface design built into it? • Are there any requirements that are essential to address while others would be nice to have but not essential?

title: Evaluate Solution Alternatives
statement: The system must provide a mechanism for managers to evaluate multiple solution alternatives and choose a system that best matches the complex and diverse organizational needs.
acceptance_criteria: The system shall provide a feature to define and weight evaluation criteria across multiple domains (e.g., functionality, security, cost, compliance).
Managers must be able to input details for at least two solution alternatives for side-by-side comparison.
The system must generate a summary report or dashboard that scores each alternative against the defined criteria.
The evaluation module must allow for attaching vendor documentation and compliance certificates for each alternative.

metadata.raw_input: EvAluAte solutions Sometimes managers will be in a position where they have multiple solution alternatives and need to choose a system that best matches the complex and diverse organizational needs.

title: Evaluate Solution Alternatives
statement: Managers will be in a position where they have multiple solution alternatives and need to choose a system that best matches the complex and diverse organizational needs.
acceptance_criteria: A documented process for evaluating and comparing solution alternatives is established and approved.
A scoring matrix is used to evaluate potential solutions against key organizational requirements, including functional, security, compliance, and financial criteria.
The final selection decision is documented, including a justification for why the chosen system best meets the organizational needs.
Evidence of stakeholder (e.g., managers, clinical leads, IT) involvement and sign-off on the final selection is available.

metadata.raw_input: EvAluAte solutions Sometimes managers will be in a position where they have multiple solution alternatives and need to choose a system that best matches the complex and diverse organizational needs.

title: Software Evaluation Trade-offs
statement: The software selection process must acknowledge that different software packages will have varying levels of strength across different requirement categories (e.g., security, usability, performance). A weighted scoring or trade-off analysis methodology must be used to evaluate and select the most suitable package based on prioritized business and clinical needs.
acceptance_criteria: A documented software evaluation plan exists that includes a weighted scoring matrix for requirement categories.
The evaluation process utilizes the scoring matrix to compare potential software packages.
The final selection report provides a clear justification for the chosen software, referencing the trade-off analysis and weighted scores.

metadata.raw_input: Not every software package will be equally strong across all requirements.

title: Balanced Requirements Assessment
statement: The software evaluation and selection process must acknowledge that different software packages will exhibit varying levels of strength across the full spectrum of requirements. A formal trade-off analysis is required to select the solution that best aligns with overall clinical and business needs, prioritizing critical requirements over less essential ones.
acceptance_criteria: A weighted scoring matrix or equivalent evaluation tool is developed and used to compare software candidates against defined requirements.
The final selection report explicitly documents the trade-off analysis, justifying the choice of software, including its strengths and acknowledged weaknesses.
Evidence exists that requirement prioritization (e.g., P1, P2, P3) was used to guide the evaluation and selection decision.

metadata.raw_input: Not every software package will be equally strong across all requirements.

title: Requirements-Driven Development Process
statement: Software functionality must be defined and implemented strictly based on approved, detailed business processes and software requirements specifications.
acceptance_criteria: All implemented software features are traceable to a corresponding approved requirement in the requirements specification document.
A traceability matrix exists and is maintained, linking business requirements to software requirements, design specifications, and test cases.
Code reviews and design reviews explicitly verify that the implementation aligns with the documented requirements.
No code is developed or committed without an associated, approved requirement or task.

metadata.raw_input: Guide softwAre Software developers are able to define the functionality of a software using the detailed business develoPment processes and requirements.

title: Implementation Flexibility for Solutions
statement: Because requirements do not specifically address how a process should be carried out, software developers are able to apply different software solutions to ensure the inputs, outputs, and outcomes match the intended objectives and goals.
acceptance_criteria: Requirement specifications focus on the 'what' (inputs, outputs, outcomes) rather than the 'how' (specific implementation details).
Design documentation demonstrates that the chosen software solution effectively meets the objectives of the requirement.
Verification and validation tests confirm that the implemented solution produces the correct outputs and outcomes as defined by the requirement, irrespective of the method used.

metadata.raw_input: Because requirements do not specifically address how a process should be carried out, software developers are able to apply different software solutions to ensure the inputs, outputs, and outcomes match the intended objectives and goals.

title: Development Aligned with Business Processes and Requirements
statement: Software developers are able to define the functionality of a software using the detailed business development processes and requirements. Because requirements do not specifically address how a process should be carried out, software developers are able to apply different software solutions to ensure the inputs, outputs, and outcomes match the intended objectives and goals.
acceptance_criteria: Traceability is established and maintained between business requirements, design specifications, and software implementation.
Design documentation clearly articulates the chosen software solution and maps its inputs, outputs, and outcomes to the objectives of the source business requirement.
Verification activities (e.g., code reviews, testing) confirm that the final software implementation meets the intended goals defined in the business requirements.

metadata.raw_input: Guide softwAre Software developers are able to define the functionality of a software using the detailed business develoPment processes and requirements. Because requirements do not specifically address how a process should be carried out, software developers are able to apply different software solutions to ensure the inputs, outputs, and outcomes match the intended objectives and goals.

title: Common Requirements Document Baseline
statement: A common requirements document shall be established and maintained to provide a standardized starting point for software design. This document must be adaptable to allow for customization to meet specific country or system needs, while ensuring the core product fulfills needs across various scheme designs and structures.
acceptance_criteria: A version-controlled common requirements document is created and approved.
The document is used as the foundational input for software design and development activities.
A documented process exists for extending or customizing the common requirements for specific implementations (e.g., country-specific regulations).

metadata.raw_input: While software may have to be further customized to meet the specific needs of a country or system, a common requirements document provides a starting point for software design and can help software developers create a product that fulfills needs across scheme designs and structures.

title: Common Requirements Baseline for Customization
statement: While software may have to be further customized to meet the specific needs of a country or system, a common requirements document provides a starting point for software design and can help software developers create a product that fulfills needs across scheme designs and structures.
acceptance_criteria: A version-controlled common requirements document exists and is used as the baseline for all software design.
Traceability is established from the common requirements document to software design specifications.
Country-specific or system-specific customizations are documented as explicit extensions or modifications of the common requirements document.

metadata.raw_input: While software may have to be further customized to meet the specific needs of a country or system, a common requirements document provides a starting point for software design and can help software developers create a product that fulfills needs across scheme designs and structures.

title: CRDM Process for Requirement Management
statement: The CRDM (Clinical Requirements Definition and Management) process shall be used to systematically identify, discuss, reach agreement on, and document any project-specific business process and its related requirements.
acceptance_criteria: A documented CRDM process is defined and available to the project team.
Evidence exists (e.g., meeting minutes, signed documents) that the CRDM process was followed for defining project requirements.
All project-specific business processes and their requirements are documented in a designated requirements management tool or document.

metadata.raw_input: Use DescriPtion Use the CRDM Process to CRDM is a generic process and can be used to identify, discuss, reach agreement on, and develoP Project-sPecific document any business process and its related requirements systematically.

title: Country/Project Level Requirement Analysis
statement: Some key processes requirements and requirements were already mapped in this document in a way that should be as generic as possible; but even then, value may be found in the analysis and consensus-building aspect of the exercise itself at a country or project level.
acceptance_criteria: Evidence of a formal analysis and consensus-building exercise at the country or project level.
A documented addendum of localized requirements or deviations is produced.
Sign-off on the localized requirements is obtained from relevant country/project stakeholders.

metadata.raw_input: Some key processes requirements and requirements were already mapped in this document in a way that should be as generic as possible; but even then, value may be found in the analysis and consensus-building aspect of the exercise itself at a country or project level.

title: CRDM Process for Business and Project Requirements
statement: The CRDM (Collaborative Requirements Development Methodology) process shall be used to systematically identify, discuss, agree upon, and document project-specific business processes and their related requirements. The analysis and consensus-building aspects of the CRDM process must be applied at the country or project level to ensure specificity and agreement, even where generic requirements have been pre-mapped.
acceptance_criteria: Evidence of CRDM process workshops being conducted for project-specific requirements is available.
Project requirements documentation is created and maintained following the CRDM process structure.
Sign-offs from key stakeholders are present on the requirements documents, indicating consensus was reached through the CRDM process.

metadata.raw_input: Use DescriPtion Use the CRDM Process to CRDM is a generic process and can be used to identify, discuss, reach agreement on, and develoP Project-sPecific document any business process and its related requirements systematically. Some key processes requirements and requirements were already mapped in this document in a way that should be as generic as possible; but even then, value may be found in the analysis and consensus-building aspect of the exercise itself at a country or project level.

title: Material and Requirement Alignment Verification
statement: Materials can be cross-checked against requirements to ensure they align with one another and that all processes are covered by both.
acceptance_criteria: A traceability matrix exists that maps requirements to corresponding materials (e.g., design documents, test cases, user guides).
A verification process confirms that 100% of requirements are covered by one or more materials.
A verification process confirms that all materials trace back to an approved requirement, ensuring no undocumented features or processes exist.
A report can be generated to show the alignment status and highlight any gaps or inconsistencies between requirements and materials.

metadata.raw_input: Materials can be cross-checked against requirements to ensure they align with one another and that all processes are covered by both.

title: Improve Data Quality
statement: The system must implement mechanisms to ensure and improve the quality, accuracy, completeness, and consistency of all stored data. This includes implementing input validation, data cleansing processes, and monitoring for common data quality issues such as duplicates, inconsistencies, and missing information.
acceptance_criteria: Input fields for critical data (e.g., date of birth, patient ID) must have format and range validation to prevent incorrect entries.
The system must include a mechanism to detect and flag potential duplicate patient records with an accuracy of at least 95%.
A data quality dashboard must be available to 'Admin' and 'Data Steward' roles, reporting on key metrics like data completeness, consistency, and error rates.
Automated data cleansing routines must run on a scheduled basis to correct common formatting issues and standardize data (e.g., phone numbers, addresses).

metadata.raw_input: ImProve dAtA quAlity Issues with data quality are common.

title: Data Flow and Process Analysis
statement: An analysis of business processes can help determine where data are entering the system (either directly collected or coming from another system), how data are processed and analyzed, and how data are shared with users and other systems.
acceptance_criteria: Data flow diagrams (DFDs) are created and maintained for all system components handling sensitive data.
A data inventory document is produced, identifying all data ingress, processing, storage, and egress points.
The analysis explicitly identifies where and how PHI/PII is collected, used, stored, and transmitted.
The documentation is reviewed and approved by the designated Security and Compliance officers.

metadata.raw_input: An analysis of business processes can help determine where data are entering the system (either directly collected or coming from another system), how data are processed and analyzed, and how data are shared with users and other systems.

title: Data Quality and Lineage Analysis
statement: The system must facilitate the analysis of business processes to identify and address data quality issues. This includes capabilities to determine data entry points (direct collection or integration), how data is processed and analyzed, and how it is shared with users and other systems.
acceptance_criteria: The system must provide a data lineage tool to trace data elements from their point of entry to all points of use and sharing.
The system must be able to generate reports on data quality metrics, including completeness, consistency, and accuracy.
An audit trail must be available to identify the source system or user for every data element.
The system must allow administrators to define and run analyses on data processing workflows to identify potential quality gaps.

metadata.raw_input: ImProve dAtA quAlity Issues with data quality are common. An analysis of business processes can help determine where data are entering the system (either directly collected or coming from another system), how data are processed and analyzed, and how data are shared with users and other systems.

title: Stakeholder Data Access for Business Processes
statement: Stakeholders are better able to address these specific issues and address data needs of each business process.
acceptance_criteria: Verify that an authorized stakeholder can access a dashboard or reporting interface tailored to their business process needs.
Verify that the interface allows the stakeholder to view and analyze data relevant to pre-defined business issues.
Verify that role-based access control is implemented, ensuring stakeholders can only access the minimum necessary data required for their role.
Verify that a stakeholder can generate or export a report containing the data needed for their specific business process.

metadata.raw_input: Stakeholders are better able to address these specific issues and address data needs of each business process.

title: Resource Usability and Maintenance
statement: The resource should be sustainably maintained, and all documentation/resources must be easily usable (e.g., downloadable, referenceable, and adaptable).
acceptance_criteria: A documented process exists for the periodic review and update of all resources, including version control.
All documentation and resources are available for download in standard, accessible formats (e.g., PDF, DOCX).
Documentation is searchable and includes a table of contents or index to facilitate easy referencing.
Where applicable, resources are provided in a format that allows for adaptation by the user's institution (e.g., templates in DOCX format).

metadata.raw_input: The resource should be sustainably maintained, and all documentation/resources must be easily usable (e.g., downloadable, referenceable, and adaptable).

title: System Scalability for National Health Schemes
statement: Globally, countries are expanding access to health services to more of their citizens through the development of national health insurance schemes; the success of these efforts is highly dependent upon effective and scalable information systems.
acceptance_criteria: The system must support a number of concurrent users equivalent to a significant percentage of the target citizen population without performance degradation.
The system must demonstrate horizontal scalability, allowing for the addition of resources to handle projected growth in users and data volume over a 5-10 year period.
Load testing must prove the system can handle peak transaction volumes (e.g., claims processing, eligibility checks) with response times under a predefined threshold (e.g., 3 seconds).

metadata.raw_input: Conclusion Globally, countries are expanding access to health services to more of their citizens through the development of national health insurance schemes; the success of these efforts is highly dependent upon effective and scalable information systems.

title: Feasibility Analysis of Common Functional Requirements
statement: An analysis must be conducted to determine the feasibility of establishing common functional requirements for a national health insurance system, considering the historical lack of reuse and standardization of such systems across different countries.
acceptance_criteria: A formal feasibility study report is produced.
The report identifies a core set of potentially common functional requirements.
The report details country-specific variations and challenges to standardization.
The report provides a recommendation on the viability of a common functional requirements approach.

metadata.raw_input: At the outset, experts questioned if common functional requirements were possible since to date there has been little reuse of national health insurance systems from country to country.

title: Scalable Information System for National Health Insurance
statement: The information system must be effective and scalable to support the expansion of access to health services for citizens under a national health insurance scheme. The system architecture must be designed to handle significant growth in user numbers, data volume, and transaction loads without degradation in performance, addressing the challenge of creating a reusable and scalable national-level platform.
acceptance_criteria: The system must support a target number of concurrent users (e.g., 1 million) with an average response time of less than 2 seconds for key transactions (e.g., eligibility check, claim submission).
The system must demonstrate horizontal scalability, allowing for the addition of compute and storage resources to increase capacity by at least 50% without service interruption.
The system must be able to process a peak load of transactions (e.g., 10,000 claims per minute) while maintaining defined performance baselines.
The data storage solution must scale to accommodate projected data growth (e.g., 20% year-over-year) for at least 10 years without requiring major architectural changes.

metadata.raw_input: Conclusion Globally, countries are expanding access to health services to more of their citizens through the development of national health insurance schemes; the success of these efforts is highly dependent upon effective and scalable information systems. At the outset, experts questioned if common functional requirements were possible since to date there has been little reuse of national health insurance systems from country to country.

title: Cross-Country Functional Requirement Harmonization
statement: Through the application of the CRDM, it is clear that countries do share many of the same functional requirements.
acceptance_criteria: A core set of functional requirements is identified and documented as common across all targeted countries.
The system architecture must be designed to support a common codebase for the identified shared functional requirements.
Country-specific variations are managed through configuration or localization settings, not through separate application builds.
Validation demonstrates that a core function (e.g., patient registration) works consistently across configurations for at least two different countries.

metadata.raw_input: Through the application of the CRDM, it is clear that countries do share many of the same functional requirements.
